title: 103_hr3300
content: The Act titled "Natural Resource Management on Military Lands Act of 1994" amends the Sikes Act of 1960, which promotes wildlife conservation on military reservations. SEC. 3. INTEGRATED NATURAL RESOURCE MANAGEMENT PLANS FOR MILITARY INSTALLATIONS. Section 101(a) (16 U.S.C. 670a(a)) is amended to require the Secretary to prepare and implement integrated natural resource management plans for each military installation in the United States. The Secretary is not required to prepare a plan for a military installation if deemed inappropriate. Title I is further amended to replace "cooperative plan" with "integrated natural resource management plan." The text chunk discusses the amendment to replace "cooperative plan" with "integrated natural resource management plan" in various sections of the legislation. The amendment replaces "cooperative plan" with "integrated natural resource management plan" in multiple sections of the legislation. The legislation amends multiple sections by replacing "cooperative plans" with "integrated natural resource management plans." It also updates the contents of plans in section 101(b). The legislation amends sections by updating the contents of plans to include wetland protection, restoration, and creation for fish and wildlife support, conservation needs for all biological communities, and specific natural resource management goals and timeframes for proposed actions. It also removes paragraph (3). The legislation updates plans to include wetland protection, restoration, and creation for fish and wildlife support, conservation needs for all biological communities, and specific natural resource management goals and timeframes for proposed actions. It also addresses the needs for fish and wildlife management, land management, forest management, and wildlife-oriented recreation, ensuring integration and consistency among activities conducted under the plan. The legislation aims to ensure no net loss in the capability of installation lands to support the military mission, provide sustained public use of natural resources, and grant public access to the installation. The legislation aims to ensure no net loss in the capability of installation lands to support the military mission, provide sustained public use of natural resources, grant public access to the installation, and enforce natural resource laws and regulations. The legislation aims to ensure no net loss in the capability of installation lands to support the military mission, provide sustained public use of natural resources, grant public access to the installation, and enforce natural resource laws and regulations. Additionally, the Secretary of Defense shall provide an opportunity for public comment on each integrated natural resource management plan prepared under subsection (a). The legislation requires a review of military installations to prepare integrated natural resource management plans. The Secretary of each military department must review all military installations in the United States to determine which ones require an integrated natural resource management plan. This report must be submitted to the Secretary of Defense within 9 months of the enactment of the Act. The Secretary of Defense must review all military installations in the United States to determine the need for an integrated natural resource management plan. A report must be submitted to Congress within 12 months, listing installations where such a plan is deemed inappropriate. The Secretary of Defense must review all military installations in the United States to determine the need for an integrated natural resource management plan. A report must be submitted to Congress within 12 months, listing installations where such a plan is deemed inappropriate. The Secretary of Defense shall establish a deadline of 2 years for the preparation of integrated natural resource management plans for military installations where such plans are deemed appropriate. The Secretary of Defense must review all military installations in the United States to determine the need for an integrated natural resource management plan. For installations where such a plan is appropriate, a plan must be prepared and implemented in agreement with the Secretary of the Interior and State agencies. If a cooperative plan is already in place, negotiations with the Secretary of the Interior must be completed. The Secretary of Defense must complete negotiations with the Secretary of the Interior and State agencies to integrate natural resource plans and allow public comments on proposed plans and changes. SEC. 5. ANNUAL REVIEWS AND REPORTS. Section 101 (16 U.S.C. 670a) is further amended by adding subsection (g) requiring the Secretary of Defense to review and report on the implementation of integrated natural resource management plans annually by March 1. The report must include the number of plans in effect for the year covered. The Secretary of Defense must annually review and report on integrated natural resource management plans, including the number of plans in effect and the amount of money spent on conservation activities. The Secretary of Defense must annually review and report on integrated natural resource management plans to ensure compliance with requirements, including no net loss of lands to support military missions. The Secretary of the Interior is also required to provide assessments on plan compliance by March 1 each year. The Secretary of the Interior must submit a report by March 1 each year on the funds spent by the Department of the Interior and State agencies for conservation activities under integrated natural resource management plans. The report on conservation activities under integrated natural resource management plans must be submitted annually by the Secretary of the Interior. Committees from the House of Representatives and Senate are defined for this purpose. SEC. 6 amends Title I to allow the Secretary of Defense to enforce Federal laws related to natural resource conservation on military installations. SEC. 7 addresses natural resource management services. SEC. 7 amends Title I to ensure that each military department has enough trained personnel for natural resource management and law enforcement to comply with the Act. SEC. 8 amends Title I by adding a new section 108 with definitions. The term 'military department' refers to the Army, Navy, and Air Force. 'Military installation' includes US-owned land administered by the Secretary of Defense or a military department. The term 'State fish and wildlife agency' refers to a state government agency responsible for managing fish and wildlife resources in the United States, including states, the District of Columbia, Puerto Rico, and other territories and possessions. SEC. 9. SHORT TITLE. Title I (16 U.S.C. 670a et seq.) is further amended by inserting after section 108 the following: "SEC. 109. SHORT TITLE. This title may be cited as the 'Sikes Act'." SEC. 10. COOPERATIVE AGREEMENTS. Cost Sharing.--Section 103a(b) is amended by replacing "matching basis" with "cost-sharing basis". Accounting.--Section 103a(c) is amended to exclude section 1535 of that title. SEC. 11. REPEAL. Section 2 of the Act of October 27, 1986 is repealed. SEC. 11. REPEAL. Section 2 of the Act of October 27, 1986 (Public Law 99-651; 16 U.S.C. 670a-1) is repealed. SEC. 12. CLERICAL AMENDMENTS. Title I, as amended by this Act, is further amended to change references from "military reservations" to "military installations" in various sections. Title I, as amended by this Act, is further amended to change references from "military reservations" to "military installations" in various sections, including sections 101, 102, and 103. SEC. 13. AUTHORIZATIONS OF APPROPRIATIONS. Amends sections related to programs on military installations and public lands by updating the years for authorizations of appropriations to 1994, 1995, 1996, and 1997. HR 3300 RS----2 was passed by the House of Representatives on September 12, 1994.
